unstyle.features package¶

Submodules¶

unstyle.features.characterfeatures module¶

Module containing character feature extractors.

unstyle.features.characterfeatures.characterSpace(text)¶

Return the total number of characters.

unstyle.features.characterfeatures.letterSpace(text)¶

Return the total number of letters (excludes spaces and punctuation)

unstyle.features.featregister module¶

The feature extractor register. This keeps track of all feature extractors. We compose feature sets (subsets of unstyle’s set of all feature extractors) by accessing this dictionary.

** The feature register should only be used by DocumentHandlers. **

Note that the featregistry is ordered.

Use the @register_feat decorator to register a feature extractor with unstyle.

unstyle.features.featregister.register_feat(func)¶

Adds decorated function to a dictionary in the form {‘name of function’:function}. For instance, we add the characterSpace feature to our registry by adding @register_feat before the definition:

@register_feat def characterSpace(text):

...

Then the state of our dictionary becomes: {‘characterSpace’ : <function characterfeatures.characterSpace>}

This makes it easy to make a featureset composed of whatever functions we would like to experiment with.

unstyle.features.lexicalfeatures module¶

Module containing lexical feature extractors.

unstyle.features.lexicalfeatures.avgSentenceLength(text)¶

Return the average length of a sentence.

unstyle.features.lexicalfeatures.avgSyllablesPerWord(text)¶

Return the average number of syllables per word.

unstyle.features.lexicalfeatures.complexity(text)¶

Return the ratio of unique words to total number of words in the document.

unstyle.features.lexicalfeatures.fleschReadingEase(text)¶

Return the Flesch reading ease score.

unstyle.features.lexicalfeatures.gunningFog(text)¶

Return the Gunning-Fog readability measure.

unstyle.features.lexicalfeatures.sentenceCount(text)¶

Get the number of sentences using NLTK’s sentence tokenizer.

unstyle.features.lexicalfeatures.unique_words(text)¶

Return the number of unique words.
